chapter.htmlHeader: Topical minoxidil 2% solution
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• Topical minoxidil 2% solution is not available to prescribe on the NHS.
  • However, it can be purchased over-the-counter, or can be obtained on a private prescription.

[BNF 71, 2016; NHS Business Services Authority, 2016]

subChapters.htmlHeader: What are the contraindications and cautions for topical minoxidil 2%?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Topical minoxidil 2% is contraindicated in women who:
    • Are not aged 18-65 years. 
    • Are hypersensitive to minoxidil, or any other ingredients such as ethanol or propylene glycol.
    • Have treated or untreated hypertension.
    • Have a skin problem on the scalp, such as psoriasis or sunburn.
    • Have a shaved scalp.
    • Are using other topical medical preparations on the scalp.
    • Are pregnant or breastfeeding.
      • There are no adequate and well controlled studies of topical minoxidil in pregnant and lactating women. Studies in animals have shown a risk to the fetus at exposure levels that are very high compared to those intended for human exposure. However, there is potentially a risk of fetal harm in humans [ABPI Medicines Compendium, 2015].
      • Minoxidil is excreted into breast milk in very small amounts. Although topical minoxidil is considered to pose a negligible risk to a breastfeeding infant [UK Drugs in Lactation Advisory Service, 2015], there is no published evidence on its safe use in breastfeeding, and the manufacturer recommends that it should be avoided in lactating women [ABPI Medicines Compendium, 2015].
  • Topical minoxidil should be used with caution in people with known cardiovascular disease or cardiac arrhythmias. 
  • Advise women to wash hands thoroughly after applying the solution.

[ABPI Medicines Compendium, 2015; BNF 71, 2016]

subChapters.htmlHeader: What are the adverse effects of topical minoxidil 2%?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Adverse effects of topical minoxidil 2% may include:
    • Hypertrichosis (unwanted non-scalp hair, including facial hair growth) in women.
      • Facial hypertrichosis has been reported to be a dose-related adverse effect in around 4% of women treated with topical minoxidil [Dawber and Rundegren, 2003; Thiedke, 2003].
      • The woman can be reassured that this hair disappears after 1 year with continued treatment. If application is discontinued, this hair disappears in 1–6 months [Herskovitz et al, 2013; Levy and Emer, 2013; Torres et al, 2015].
    • Local redness, itching, and flaking. Skin reactions are largely due to the presence of the propylene glycol vehicle.
      • Treatment should be discontinued if there is persistent redness or irritation of the scalp. 
    • Increased hair shedding generally occurring 2–6 weeks after initiating treatment. It is temporary and subsides within a few weeks.
      • Treatment should be discontinued if shedding persists for more than 2 weeks.
  • There is no clear increased risk of cardiovascular complications with the use of topical minoxidil (because systemic absorption through normal skin is very low). However, cases of hypotension have been reported rarely, and treatment should be discontinued if the woman experiences chest pain, syncope, or dizziness. 
  • The manufacturer also recommends discontinuing treatment if the person experiences sudden unexplained weight gain, or swollen hands or feet.

[ABPI Medicines Compendium, 2015; BNF 71, 2016]

subChapters.htmlHeader: What are the drug interactions of topical minoxidil 2%?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• There is a theoretical possibility that absorbed minoxidil can potentiate orthostatic hypotension caused by other antihypertensive drugs.
  • Application of other topical drugs, such as topical corticosteroids, tretinoin, or dithranol, may increase absorption of minoxidil.

[ABPI Medicines Compendium, 2015]
